1.content:
Bella woke up with a start. She couldn't understand why her heart was beating so fast and she felt so panicky. She got out of bed and went to the window. It was just possible that her friend Will might be throwing stones at her window. He had periodic emergencies when family fights broke out and he'd often ended a bad night crashing on her family sofa.

There was nobody in the broad street below her window. Her bedroom overlooked the high street of Rawley, from above the gas station her father ran.

She must have had a nightmare, she decided. Funny, she couldn't remember what she had been dreaming about.




The following day she was at Rawley to see Will.
"-I don't know, it was a really disturbing feeling" she said.

"It was just a bad dream" said Will, in a reassuring voice. He wanted to talk about something he had found in the library next to the boys' common room. He couldn't understand why such a large collection of occult texts were lying around where impressionable teenagers might find them. Rawley was an expensive school, and the faculty worried a lot about upsetting parents. He looked at Scout, thinking that they didn't come much more impressionable than his room mate.

Scout, designer-clad, beautiful, and very very dim, was more sympathetic. "Are you all right?" he gasped. He quite fancied Bella, but he was playing it cool, he thought proudly.

"Of course she is" said Will. "She's my oldest friend, I'd know if she wasn't. Look, Bella, can we talk about this later? There's a new English teacher just in, and I need to find out whether I can change my essay topic. His name's Finn. Do you think he's Irish?"

"Would Bella know if he was?" Scout queried, wide eyed.

"There might be gossip in town."

"I'd expect more gossip here. This affects you more than me."

"Well, Hamilton might know something" Will conceded. "But, you know, he's a bit weird."
1.title: Bella Wakes

11.content:
"When I say it's a library" Will said "it's more, like, a corner of the boys' common room. But there are some great books there.. Faulkner, Whitman, Hawthorne, Melville, Twain, Scott Fitzgerald."

"I read Tom Sawyer once" announced Scout.

"Did they ever make a movie of that?"

Will huffed a sigh. "Phillistines." He handed Bella a baggy sweatshirt and a cap. "In case we run into faculty. Amazingly, not all of them fear the Power that is the Banks."

"They should; they've all got fallible car engines" she said casually.

Will looked at her sternly: since getting into Wicca, he'd been trying to explain to her about the sevenfold rule. "I was joking Will" she would reply. "Sarcasm. Look it up."

Scout got bored with the meaningful looks and big words. "Let's go."
11.title: setting off for the library

111.content:
Bella and the boys were half way down the stairway when they were interrupted. "Uh oh" said Will.

"Tellytubbie impersonations, William? How sweet." A tall blond boy with an English accent had intercepted them.

"It's from England's rich cultural heritage, am I right?" Will nudged Bella behind him. Ryder's observational skills tended to kick in at the most awkward moments. And Will didn't think Bella made the world's most convincing boy. Scout, taking Will's cue, tugged Bella away, while Will sparred with Ryder.

Scout kept them moving at speed till they reached the lawn. "It's okay" he reassured the unconcerned Bella. "He won't follow us into the sunlight."

"Who is the cute guy?" And how, Bella wondered, did they get to the library from here?

"His name's Ryder. He arrived here two nights ago with a huge Fortnum and Mason's hamper with soil leaking out of the wickerwork." Scout frowned. He hadn't thought about it, but "He's a bit strange."

"Pretentious" Bella suggested. It was the townie's catch-all explanation for Rawley weirdness. "Where's the library from here?"

Scout pointed to a window. "I've never been there, but that room has a lot of books in it" he guessed.

Bella remembered something Scout had said. "Why won't Ryder come outdoors?"

"He has sensitive skin" Scout sneered. "He doesn't know the rules of football either." Satisfied that he had put Bella off Ryder, he added, "Did I tell you that I made crew?"
111.title: Ryder is strange. In Scout's opinion

1111.content:
Will couldn't stand Ryder, arrogant pretentious wealthy pig.

All right, he maybe didn't mind the pretentious bit. But Ryder made him look stupid, and he was malicious and unpredictable. He got that sociopath glint in his eye, and Will would get scared. He felt like Ryder might do anything, but didn't know what, and that, he'd explained to Scout, was what bothered him. If he didn't know what Ryder would do, he couldn't plan how to react.

Will liked to keep a handle on things.

Ryder didn't give him as much grief as, say, Ham or Harry Johnson - Will and Scout sincerely pitied Harry for being stuck as Ryder's room mate - but those two losers were just born to be school victims.

Still, Will avoided Ryder whenever possible, and this time, he got away from him as soon as he could.




back, and follow Scout + Bella please.
1111.title: brief encounter

1112.content:
"Yes" said Bella, staring through the window. "You told me." She started fiddling with the catch.

"Are you going in through the window?" Scout wondered what her problem was with the usual route.

"Those panelled corridors are a maze." Bella swung herself over the sill. "Besides, for all I know, there's closed circuit TV covering the whole school." (And that had only occurred to her just now.) Bella grimaced.

Scout didn't think that kind of security was in place. The staff would have a much clearer idea of what was going on if there were cameras. And so far, the faculty struck him as pretty clueless. Nevertheless, he swung himself over the sill in Bella's wake.

The room was empty of people. He thought so, anyway, but the light level was much lower, coming in from the bright sunlight. The walls were dark, and the furniture ran to big squashy leather sofas and wing chairs. They were comfortable. Scout liked them.

Bella thought it was an insistently male decor. "Smells of money" she said, looking around. "Where are these books? Will anyone notice if we take them to show Will?" She strode off to the stacks in the corner - not a true library, just a part of the room arrannged so that it had become like an extensive maze of shelves. Musty and clearly untouched volumes in leather binding loomed high over Bella's head. The titles she saw amazed her so much, she was drawn farther and farther into the stacks.

Scout hesitated. He thought he'd heard a noise, a yip of nerves from someone. "Who's th-" It was Harry Johnson. "Oh. Hey, whats up, man."

Harry was in a darkened corner of the room. Alone. Pretending to revise. Scout felt sorry for him. Harry was so shy it almost counted as a disability. Scout had never been mean to him, so why Harry should have no problem talking to him.. "Harry?"

"I'm sorry, I'm sorry" Harry chanted. It was the sort of thing Harry would say, so Scout paid it no mind, until he felt the sharp pain in the crook of his neck. "Harry, man, what the hell-?"
1112.title: wild about harry

choices: Scout convinces Bella not to go there
11121.content:
Bella was horrified to return to the common room and find Scout overcome by some stranger.

This weird guy was actually doing some kind of vampire attack, and that was just freakish. This whole school, she thought distastefully, was just a pit of creepy, superstitious - without reflection, Bella had grabbed an oar from where it leaned against a wall, and tucked it under her armpit like a lance. "Let's see if this staking gig works" she muttered.

Mid-lunge, startled, she realised what she was doing. It was like an instinct. And it was too late to pull out of the fight. Personal pull with the local cops wasn't going to help if this guy wasn't undead, and as a sensible modern girl, Bella had problems with this Hammer Horror shit ..oh. Dusted. Inside, part of her was screaming.

"I guess he was a vampire" she said.

"Urrgh."

"Scout? Hold this hanky over the cut and press hard. I'll phone 911."

"Covered in oil" Scout objected.

"Don't be picky" Bella said in a tone she'd perfected over years of Grace. "I'm a mechanic, remember?"

Scout looked round. "Where's Johnson?"

"The guy nibbling your neck? You were friends?" Rawley College. Freakier and freakier.

"I wouldn't say that, man. I can't believe he did that." Scout shook his head incautiously. "Ow."

"No." Bella put down the phone. Scout didn't seem as much of a medical emergency as, in her first panic, she'd thought. She felt a little shaky.

"How did you know what to do?"

"They show a lot of hackneyed horror at the local drive in."

"Really?" Scout thought, maybe I need to know this stuff. "Would you like to go with me?" Oh, why would a hot girl like her be impressed by him, he thought. He'd have to add some inducements. "Moonlight, jujubees, cheesy dialogue?"

Bella laughed. Scout was cute, after all. "OK. Is the cheesy dialogue going to be you or the movie?"

Scout decided honesty might be the best policy. "Both."

Bella frowned at the little pile of dust that had been Harry Johnson. "Did you know he was a vampire?" Anything seemed possible.

"No." Scout looked indignant. Then he said in self defence "he can't have been one for long. He was trying out for crew, this afternoon in the sunshine."

"When was that?"

"A couple of hours ago." Scout worked out what Bella was getting at. "Then he went to his dorm."

"Let's go."

"No!" Scout looked scared.

"Why?"

"He shared a dorm with Ryder. You don't want to mess with Ryder."
11121.title: dust to dust

111211.content:
"Ryder? Isn't Will talking to him?"

"Oh" said Scout. "Yeah."

"So, we're cool. He's busy." Bella set off. "Come on Scout. I need you to show me where this dorm is?"

Mumbling, Scout trudged after her. Was this the best way she could think of to spend an afternoon?

"We don't get cable." Bella shrugged. "Sean and Will and I were always curious about this place. God, and I always thought the Edmund High rumours were lies."

Scout protested. "I'm really normal."

Bella looked him up and down. "I don't think so."

Harry's dorm was almost completely dark. Heavy blinds were drawn across the window. Scout wrinkled his nose.

"It's like a lair" said Bella. She looked round interestedly.

"Still with the blood loss, here."

"Uh huh." Bella was using a pen to prod at piles of laundry. Ew.

"What if Ryder and Will have finished talking. What if Ryder is headed right this way. What if he's coming here now."

"What's this?" Bella had found a book, like the ones in the library. It had been under Harry's sweaty shirts. She read the title aloud. "On the Summoning of Demons."

Freaky. "Nobody believes in that crap."

Bella decided to return it to the library. It must have come from there. "It doesn't explain why Harry became a-"

"A what?" Scout was moving to the land of denial. "I told you, nobody believes in that crap."

"A -" Bella felt stupid too. "Never mind." She looked around for something to distract both of them. "Why is there that big crate of soil marked Hyde Park?"

1112111.content:
"Oh, crap" said Scout. All this tired gothic business was stressing him out. He wanted a nurse, even a 500lb nurse like the one in Will's story, and he was sick of Bella and everyone else.

He walked over to the window while Ryder was purring menaces at Bella, and ripped the blind up.

Ryder left rather suddenly.

Bella stared after him. She had disliked him viscerally, and she wasn't sure why. She said so.

"I can't stand him either. You're showing good character judgement." Although, Bella did seem blind to Scout's character. She hadn't shown any interest in him at all. His neck hurt. "Can we go now?"

11121112.content:
Bella brings the spell book to Will, who begins to flip through it, as excited as a kid in a candy store.

Scout is watching, and he's still feeling a bit off by Ryder showing up on them when he did. Bella didn't seem phased by it. She seemed to keep her cool quite well and Scout wondered how she did that.

Will looked through the book and whistled. "Wow...this book is heavy."

Bella frowned. "I didn't think it was heavy. It probably weighs only a couple of pounds."

"I don't think that's what Will meant," Scout informed her.

"Oh...I knew that." She frowned. "Will, what's so heavy about it?"

"There are spells in here to summon creatures and demons from other hell dimensions," Will said. "Why would Ryder want this book? Is he trying to bring demons here...or something else?" He looked at the back of the book and someone had written something there. Probably the original owner. Someone named Michael. He read it outloud. "'The dead shall be set free and the stars themselves shall hide. From the blackest pits of Hades, it awakens and no one shall be able to hide.' 'For Michael with much love and devotion...Diana.'"

"Who's Michael?" Bella asked.

"Who's Diana?" Scout wondered.

Will frowned in thought. "Maybe Ryder knows, but...what's all that other stuff in there about the black pit and no one will be able to hide?" He frowned harder. "I used to be able to hide pretty good when I was a kid. No one could find me."

Bella felt an instinct coming upon her and she wondered where it was coming from. It was almost like she knew what must be done. "I know what we should do."

The others looked at her and waited.
11121112.title: The Spellbook

11122.content:
Scout was shocked into paralysis for a minute before he fought back. When did Harry get so strong? and, (come to think of it this was a more pressing question,) why would anyone do anything this gross? He was actually sucking Scout's neck. Ew.

Scout managed to dislodge Harry, and staggered back. "What the hell, man? Is this some kind of frat cult?" And, he added silently, why hadn't he been asked. He was a Calhoun, after all. His dad would be so disappointed in him if with his connections he couldn't manage to be some kind of popularity king. He thought - I mean, obviously, I'd've said NO, cause, firstoff, unhygenic, and, yaknow, standards, but kind of rude not to give me the refusal -

Not answering about the frat cult thing, Harry hurled himself back at Scout like a rugby tackler. He'd never been the big contact sports fan hitherto, although this wasn't the most constructive thought Scout could have had right then. Weakened by blood loss, Scout didn't throw him off again.

It wasn't long before Harry stood over him. "oh God, oh God.." Harry felt just awful. The bewilderment and hunger had passed now. It left room for an all embracing guilt. He realised what he had become.

Scout peered through the gathering dark. "Harry?" His voice was whispery.

"I never meant -" Harry sobbed. Scout was always kind to him. Dumb, yeah, sure, but kind. This was one of the last guys in Rawley to deserve such an end. Frantically, Harry scrabbled at his own wrist. He had thought of a solution.. "Scout! Drink this!"

Scout looked at the red drops welling from Harry's cut hand. "Ew. Gross."

"Just do it. All right."

"Call 911." Scout gasped. He pressed his hand to his neck.

"Think of it as a transfusion-"

A minute later, Scout was climbing to his feet. He looked dazed. "I feel weird" he announced.

"You're undead, man."

"Huh?"

"You're, like, my minion."

"I So am not." What kind of kinky shit was Harry suggesting?

"No." Harry guessed Scout needed smaller words. "It's like, I'm your Sire, and you're my _"

Scout was peering at him, his expression still cloudy.

"You take orders from me" Harry explained.

"Do not." Johnson was the official Class Nerd. While Scout had nothing against him as a person, his pride revolted at the thought of taking any crap from a social leper.

"I have to take orders from Ryder" Harry pointed out.

"Don't have to" Scout mumbled. "It's just he makes you look stupid if you don't do what he says."

"Ryder made me."

With care - he was still a little dizzy - Scout focussed his attention on Harry. "What are you saying?"

"Ryder made me a vampire, so he's my Si - uh, boss. And now I made you."

Scout had an uneasy memory of the longago time he'd kept a stray puppy in the utility room for weeks because his mom had allergies and wouldn't let him have a pet. The puppy's owners had been so mad at him.. The memory passed. He felt a wave of hunger. His gut cramped, and he felt his face scrunch up somehow. "Need-"

Harry looked worried. "Oh, dear."

A voice called from the stacks. "Scout? Where are you? I thought you were right here-"

Harry turned round hastily, tripping over an oar. "I forgot about the girl." He wasn't hungry anymore, so he didn't need her. But now he ought to think of what his Childe needed..

"That's Bella." Scout wondered why his voice sounded different. "She's pretty."

This was awkward. "Do you like her?" Maybe she wasn't Scout's ideal breakfast.

"Uhh-"
111221.title: Daddy, can I have a pet?

1112211.content:
"Quick! Come on." Harry grabbed Scout's arm and dragged him out of the room.

He wasn't going to let Scout kill his girlfriend, or whoever this chick was. If Harry had to be a vampire, (and it looked like he didn't have a choice,) he was going to be a vampire with soul. Like that mopey one in the Anne Rice books. Yeah.

"Huh?" said Scout.

It was true, Harry reflected. Vamping really didn't alter people's essential personalities. "You're hungry, right?"

Scout nodded vigorously, still crunkle-faced. Rawley students weren't too observant, but Harry picked up the pace anyway. Someone might notice.

They got to Harry's dorm. Scout looked around. He saw no food. Harry was fumbling with a big leather bound book. They'd just left a whole roomful of books like that behind. What was Harry playing at? Absently, Scout scooped Harry's illicit guinea pig out of its cage and raised it to his mouth.

"No! Bad!" Harry rushed over and saved Muggles. "Look, it's alright. I can get you food." He picked the book up again. This spell book summons up demons, and it can't be evil to eat demons, right?"

"Demons?" That sounded dangerous, but, now that he thought about it, today Scout felt mean and dangerous himself. Hey, he could deal with demons.

"We'll start this easy" Harry said prudently. "This one's a jake."

Scout wondered what it would taste like, but he was too hungry to worry much about that. He was big, and bad, and nothing could stand in his way.
1112211.title: Bad idea. Bad, bad idea.

11122112.content:
The jake they summoned looked unexpectedly like the new coxswain Ham had brought to the last crew session. Never mind, Scout was too hungry to stress about details. He stepped up to it.

"Excuse me? What the hell do you think you're doing?" It had a very biting tone of voice. It sounded authoritative, like the coxswain. Scout was stopped in his tracks.

Actually, Scout hadn't bargained for it having a voice at all. He felt vaguely wrong about eating something he'd held a conversation with. He came to a lightening conclusion. He was going to have to eat faster, so's not to connect with it emotionally.

At this point, the jake hit him. Scout felt majorly aggrieved.

"Hey! Don't do that" Harry protested on his behalf. Harry was acting like they were buddies all of a sudden.

"And who are you?" The jake looked them both up and down scornfully. Apparantly Scout was going to have to engage with it socially after all.

It looked kind of like a girl. That was one difference between it and the coxswain. Scout sighed. He realised the jake had become an acquaintence. He could never eat it now.

"You honestly think you're bad enough to take me on you stupid fledglings" the jake sneered.

OK, he couldn't eat it, but he thought he could probably manage to dislike it. Scout didn't know what fledglings meant, but the demon was saying it like it was an insult.

Beside him, Harry glared resentfully. Scout made a note to ask him about the fledglings thing, later. "We summoned you to Eat" said Harry. "We are - aarrgh"

Scout stared, freaked out, at the pile of dust that had been Harry Johnson. The demon left him, and the dimension, in contempt. It took the spell book with it.

"Harry-" Scout pinched himself. No, not a dream. He didn't even believe in spells and crap like that.

He decided to ask roomie for advice. Will was into this kind of nonsense, and he was a friend. Suddenly remembering the danger of Ryder reappearing - this was his dorm, after all - Scout hurried out the door.

He was still hungry, anyway. He decided to call by the canteen. Rare bloody steak would be nice. He took Muggles with him. Warm. Strokable. Not enough there to spoil his appetite.

111221121.content:
The only problem was, the canteen was located across a courtyard. Scout felt an irrational sense of unease as he got to the door. The rays of light slanting into the panelled hallway just gave him a very bad feeling. There was nothing worse than dust motes suspended in them, but still the glowing light intimidated him. He slowed as he moved closer, which was as well -

"Ow!" That burned.

Scout fell back, and studied the smoke rising from his forearm. Muggles took the opportunity to spring out of his hold. Scout didn't notice.

He must've been hurt more than he'd assumed, during that weird session in the library. He didn't know what Johnson had done to him there, and now that Johnson had been turned to dust - and things like that weren't supposed to happen in real life, but it definitely had happened.. Scout sighed, confused. He was gonna have to talk seriously to Will. Will did spells, and he was really smart. Will could help him.

But first, Scout had to have something to eat. He was so hungry. A thick broth would be nice. Solids just didn't appeal..

A horrible pattern was forming, here, but Scout firmly refused to acknowledge the implications. He just didn't want to know this.

"Grrrr." Something was behind him.

It was one of the Fleming family dogs. They had free run of the school. Without thinking, Scout pounced on it. He was more of an animal than stupid WeegeeEvans would ever be, ha! It was like he was in some altered mental state. He was so fast, so strong, so unstoppable, it was like descriptions of being on drugs, or something.

After, he felt sick in the head. (But undeniably healthier and much less hungry.) He had liked that dog, up till then. (But, better to do that to a dog than a person, he told himself.) It looked like Johnson had made him a vampire, he couldn't deny it. (Lousy Johnson.)

He was still a good guy, though. He was (averting his gaze from the carcasse) not a killer, or something nasty. Will was gonna help him, right?

And if Will didn't, maybe he should make a call.

Scout slipped back to his room by a shady route.
111221121.title: Scout becomes  self aware

1112211211.content:
Scout was mildly offended by the way Will was perched on the windowsill all through their conversation, with sunlight spilling all around him. Did he not trust Scout, or something?

They were roomies, for pity's sake, and Scout had explained how he hadn't killed anyone so he wasn't a bad person- "-and I was soo tempted, 'cause its like, a craving-"

Oops. Shouldn't've said that. It didn't reassure the guy like it should've. He was giving testimony to his strength of will, okay?

He hadn't mentioned the dog. Krudsky was having trust issues. Besides, it wasn't like an actual person had been hurt.

Will was staring at him. Scout shifted uncomfortably.

"There's a beat up looking scroll on the chest of drawers under the baseball mitt" Will said.

"Is there?" Scout replied blankly. He was worrying about Will's tone, which was perfectly unreadable.

Will rolled his eyes. "Pass it to me. It's a gypsy curse."

"Curse!" Scout yelped. Hadn't he suffered enough? He hadn't asked for this, this, affliction, and was there a support group, a charity, some lobbying for research, with celebrities making speeches - maybe Johnny Depp, and Anjelica Huston, and -

"To get you back your soul" Will told him.

Scout looked sulky. He hadn't noticed losing it.

Will muttered "-and if it can give you a brain too.."

"Will it work?"

That was the thing. Will didn't know. He glanced nervously at the lengthening shadows.
1112211211.title: a little help from my friends

11122112111.content:
If Will was going to do this, he'd better do it now. Thing was, all the stuff he needed was over on the other side of the room, and, well, he was okay with keeping in this patch of sunlight.

The window sill was digging into his bum, but he wasn't going anywhere.

Scout made an observation, apparantly to kickstart the conversation. "The sky's getting dark."

Will didn't have much time. He would have to do this now, but the spell needed - wait! He could send Scout to get ingredients. Yeah, brilliant. Scout would have to trek all round town.

Will was getting nervous about being near Scout. "I need, uh, hair from when you were human."

Scout pointed to a brush on his bedstand. It was five feet away. So much for trekking all round town.

Will gave the bedstand a jaundiced look. "Pestle and mortar."

"You've got those." Will had explained which was which when they unpacked.

"Oh yeah." Hell, thought Will.

"A handfull of mustard seeds, a priest's collar, a box of matches, a moonlit night, a lot of chanting, a stoup of holy water (stolen), a clove of garlic." He rattled off the rest of the stuff in a breath.

Scout hesitated. "I don't think I like garlic anymore."

"It's necessary."

Scout looked worried. "Where are you going to find the holy water?"

"You're going to find it. This is your thing. Don't you want your soul back?"

Scout shrugged. He felt got at.

"You go and get that holy water. There's a church on the other side of town." Will added more kindly "You can borrow my bike."

"But I'm a - I can't touch that stuff."

"You're a creature of the night. You can do anything you want." Will pushed him through the door.

"-out of school bounds" he wailed from the corridor. "The Dean will be mad-"

The lock clicked behind him.
11122112111.title: Separation Anxiety

111221121111.content:
Getting the mustard seed was easy. A quick raid on the kitchen took care of it. It was bizarre; Scout knew the smell in there should make his mouth water, but it did nothing for him any more.

Matches, and a box of illicit cigarettes, were on a grimy ledge by a staff fire escape.

Scout didn't smoke. He wasn't sure if he could now. Was he breathing? He paid attention for a minute - yes, he was. However, he wasn't sure he needed to. It could be habit. After all, he'd been breathing for years.

On the way over the open ground, heading for the trees beyond which lay New Rawley, Scout held his breath. It was kind of a scientific experiment. He really didn't need air. Also, his night vision was better.

New stuff kept coming up. This was so starting to freak him out. He wished he had someone to compare notes with. Even Harry Johnson would do. He'd never got to talk properly to his sire.

Harry Johnson was dead. Scout was only assimilating that now. He'd been in shock. That chick had killed him, just like that. She was one to avoid, all right.

She was a friend of Krudsky's. Avoidance could be a problem. Scout wondered uneasily if Krudsky's spell was totally beneficial to Scout.

Grrr sounded from the darkness in the woods.

Scout jumped. He forgot again that he was the predator.
111221121111.title: Heart of Darkness

1112211211111.content:
Scared stiff, Scout backed away from the growling bear. It's neck and shoulders were all muscle. Biting it would be like sucking a quarterback through his shoulder pads. His poor little fangs wouldn't stand a chance.

Really, it was amazing that childrens' toys were based on a carnivore. Why weren't toddlers everywhere clutching plush.. moo-cows? OK, Scout was officially losing it. He even thought the creature was talking..

"Who'rrre you?"

"Scout Calhoun." His voice was a squeak. "Pleased to meet you." Now that was a social lie. He was falling back on small talk.

"Patty bearrr."

Scout glanced at the bear's paw. I'm not shaking that, he thought. The claws were awesome. Scout was sure that, even if she couldn't kill him, and to be honest, he didn't want to rely on the unproven immortal thing, this bear could put him through a world of pain.

"I'm not a bearrr."

"You look like a bear" Scout pointed out. He couldn't help himself.

"I'm a film studies majorrr."

This seemed unlikely, and Scout was used to unlikely. "On your way to Hollywood?" he babbled. Great, carnivorous and geographically challenged. "You're kind of lost." Rawley might be nearer Hollywood than her home, though. Scout was picking up an accent. "Are you Australian? How'd you get here?" Scout was so curious, he stopped edging backwards.

The bear looked embarrassed. "I think I computerrr coded myself into this. It was late, I'd been typing forrr hourrrs. Stupid HTML."

Scout nodded, confused. "Can't you HTML your way out?"

Silently, the bear held up a vast paw. It was poorly adapted to a keyboard. Tactlessly, Scout said so. "-but hey, great for batting salmon out of the lake!"

Patty growled.

"How're you going to get out of this?" Scout really wanted to know.

"Kiss me you fool."

"Huh?"

"Everrr rrread Beauty and the Beast? I need a handsome prrrince. I'll kiss everrry boy in Rrrrawley. Woohoo. Starrrting with the cute ones." Patty had an air of great decision. "And You arrre going to help me."
1112211211111.title: Lions and tigers and ..no, just bears.

1112212.content:

Obviously, there was a high turnover. That was the nature of the thing. He had confidently expected an astonishingly long, productive, and fully pensioned retirement with his true love, Shakespearian criticism.

But that cheerful acceptance of his slayer's death pre-dated meeting Bella. It seemed a grotesque attitude now. If Bella died of sheer ignorance, it would be on his head.

Finn looked at the phone in his hand. He'd met this man once, at a party in the Cotswolds. Giles had been a bit of a black sheep to the Council, and Finn had not liked to associate too openly with him. One thing Finn did remember about what Giles had said.

Giles had talked about his early experiences with that valley girl slayer. He had found her completely alien and impossible to deal with. Giles might be able to give Finn some useful advice now.

He hadn't expected to need to go running for help so soon.

He had just dialled the number and was listening to it ringing when he heard a sound behind him. "Who's there?" There was an unWatcherlike quaver in his voice. It occurred to him that he was going to have to earn that long, peaceful academic messing about with Shakespeare that he so anticipated.
